author: bozoconnors
body: New-ish myself.  If by "brands" you mean brokers...  quite happy with Fidelity myself.  Great website.  Great app.  $0 trades.  Active Trader Pro desktop client is capable of more info than I'll *ever* use & allows near instant trading.  I hear Schwab is also great.

author: Eman270

author: JezusBakersfield
body:
I haven't used TD but re: RH, Fidelity is also same thing with better pre trade/after market hours + partial shares and instant deposit. No bullshit limits, no fees. Only you need good credit for margin or options and a decent history.

Also trades themselves execute MUCH better. I feel like I've been ripped off on everything I do on RH and there's this annoying delay half the time for confirmations. The only thing you can't do on Fidelity that you can on RH is crypto -- and in that case, RH rounds up 1% or down 3% unless you do limit order and YMMV w trades. Just about done w RH today...

author: instagunny
body:
*Apocryphal* Fidelity study, although the lesson is true enough.  

https://mobile.twitter.com/jposhaughnessy/status/1155171083663925248  
> When I went looking for it, I found nothing. Pure Urban Legend.  

https://www.nytimes.com/2016/08/06/your-money/401k-retirement-plan-investment-stock-markets.html
> Fidelity, which has received inquiries about the study ever since, without knowing why, told me this week that it had never produced such a study.

author: BillNye69
body:
I have $75k I’d like to put into a brokerage account, Fidelity or Vanguard. My question is, which is the better plan:

1. Depositing all $75k into Fidelity but straight into a money market fund, and then DCAing (say 2k) from the money market fund each week into Fidelity S&P500, in order to ask Fidelity for a signup bonus since I deposited all 75k at once into the brokerage account. (Not sure how much Fidelity would offer me—anyone know?). 

2. Just setting up DCA (same 2k) per week from my savings account into Fidelity S&P500.

author: oklastfuckingtime
body:
u/dawgsjw u/Dontcaredaily

I use fidelity. I have active trader Pro which would be similar to think or swim just on the fidelity platform. So when you make an account, you have to call them and ask for extended hours trading. It's really as easy as calling. You may have to have a minimum amount of money in the account but I honestly don't remember.

My understanding regarding the EH swings is large institutions/big buyers can cause price fluctuations based on the number of shares they buy/sell. Very few shares are traded in extended hours which is why you will see a huge price swing.

The earliest I can trade is 7am central time and as late as 7pm central time I think. I don't do after market trading so I'm not so sure on the back end

author: xLitecoin
body: I lost 2,000 in profits already this morning because I couldn’t sell and who knows how much more it will be, I couldn’t sell my puts let alone any trade this morning. Who is going to reimburse me? I already filed a complaint with the sec, something needs to be done. No other brokerage goes through problems like this every time their is a high trading volume. Absolutely incapable of doing their job but by golly the new referral program and fractional shares are more important ??? Who wants that shit when the main trading platform can’t even function correctly. Then you call customer service and they tell you to send an email to support that is not working as well. This is a full circle jerk and I’m done with this shit. TD, Fidelity, Charles Schwab, who knows but anything is better then this neck beard infested wannabe trading site.

author: MartianManhunter0987
body:
Fidelity is a well established player with a very large number of features. Robinhood is a relatively new entrant with very limited features. 

If you ask me you should open accounts with both as both of them are free. 

\- Use fidelity to open IRA accounts (IRA Roth as well) 

\- Fidelity now lets you trade in fractional shares

\- Use Robinhood for your day to day trading and to learn about trading. 

&#x200B;

Robinhood has significantly better app interface.
